data.title: John C. Fremont – The Pathfinder – Legends of America
data.meta_description: John Fremont was an explorer, military officer, and politician who led multiple surveying expeditions through the West.
data.text:
John Charles Fremont was an explorer, surveyor, military officer, and politician who led five western expeditions.

On January 21, 1813, Fremont was born in Savannah, Georgia, to Charles Fremon, a French-Canadian schoolteacher, and Anne Beverley Whiting, the youngest daughter of socially prominent Virginia planter Colonel Thomas Whiting. When his father died when John was just five years old, the family moved to Charleston, South Carolina, where he attended college before being expelled for irregular attendance. However, he’d done well in math and got a teaching job on a warship.

His career as an explorer began when he left the Navy to join the United States Topographical Corps, later becoming the Army Corps of Engineers. In 1838, he was commissioned a second lieutenant by President Van Buren. In that year and the next, he took part in Jean Nicollet’s expedition to the plains between the upper Mississippi and Missouri Rivers. Becoming an expert in geology and topography, he headed his own expedition to survey the Des Moines River in 1841. On October 19, 1841, he secretly married Jessie, daughter of Thomas H. Benton, even though her parents objected to the union based on her age.

For the next ten years, Fremont explored the country between the Missouri River, the Rocky Mountains, and the Pacific Coast (see Fremont’s Expeditions.) His reports gave many their first knowledge of what is now the many states of the American West, and his work won him the nickname “Pathfinder.”

Landing in California with his wife, Fremont led much of the revolt in Alta that led to the state’s admission to the Union. During the Mexican-American War, Commodore Robert Stockton was appointed civil governor. Trouble brewed within the American ranks when Fremont refused to recognize Brigadier General Stephen Kearny’s authority to organize a new territorial government. After Washington D.C. confirmed Kearny’s authority, Fremont was arrested for mutiny, disobedience, and improper conduct. Kearny would return with Fremont to Fort Leavenworth, Kansas, in August of 1847 for trial. Fremont was found guilty; however, President Polk commuted his sentence and was reinstated.

He became a millionaire when gold was found on the land he purchased in the Sierra foothills. He then moved to politics, serving as one of California’s first senators. The first Republican National Convention in 1856 nominated him for the presidency, and he received 114 electoral votes, but James Buchanan received 174 and went on to win the election.

Soon after the Civil War began, he was made a major-general and assigned to the command of the Western Department, with headquarters at St. Louis, Missouri. On August 31, 1861, he proclaimed martial law and the emancipation of the slaves belonging to those in arms against the government. President Abraham Lincoln endorsed the proclamation, except for that part concerning emancipation, but Fremont refused to rescind it, and the president’s order finally annulled it. This and other complaints caused him to be relieved of his command, but he was placed in command of the mountain district in Kentucky, Tennessee, and Virginia the following spring. Fremont asked to be relieved when his command was made a part of General John Pope’s Army of Virginia. His request was granted, and this ended his military career.

Afterward, he lost his fortune through bad railroad investments and moved to Arizona, where he was made territorial governor from 1878 to 1883. In 1887, Fremont returned to California. General Fremont was the author of various works, most of them relating to his explorations. He died on July 13, 1890, in New York City.
